title.narrative: HEARD - Förbättrad tillgång till SRHR för alla - 2018-2021
HEARD - Realisation of SRHR for all - 2018-2021

description.narrative:
HEARD, ett multidisciplinärt forsknings- och utbildningsinstitut vid University of KwaZulu-Natal, Sydafrika, har ansökt om finansiering från det regionala SRHR-teamet vid Ambassaden i Lusaka. Förslaget från HEARD omfattar ett fyraårigt program 2018-2021 till en kostnad motsvarande cirka 78 miljoner kronor.
Programmet syftar till att främja och stödja SRHR arbetet i södra och östra Afrika genom att generera ny kunskap och att stödja användningen av kunskap i beslutsfattande inom hälsa och SRHR-området. HEARD syftar till att (i) minska avståndet mellan forskning och beslutsfattare, (ii) genomföra riktad, tillämpad, forskning för att göra politiska och finansiella investeringar inom SRHR mer effektiva. (iii) skapa en regional plattform för evidensbaserat beslutsfattande inom SRHR och hälsa.
HEARD kommer inom ramen för interventionen att bedriva tillämpad forskning, genomföra forskningsutbildningar och utbildningar för beslutsfattare och slutligen bedriva påverkansarbete gentemot beslutsfattare.
Ambassaden har samarbetat med HEARD sedan drygt tio år tillbaka och under den senaste insatsperioden (2011-2017) har Ambassaden gett HEARD kärnstöd. Det är ambassadens bedömning att HEARD under kommande projektperiod måste minska sitt beroende av kärnfinansiering från Sverige och skapa en långsiktigt hållbar grund för finansiering.

Then intervention comprises support to HEARD at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, SA, for advancing SRHR priorities across the Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) region. The overarching goal of the intervention is to ensure that the uptake of robust, comprehensive evidence drives improvement in SRHR across ESA.

title.narrative: HEARD - Realisation of SRHR for all - 2018-2021
HEARD - Realisation of SRHR for all - 2018-2021

description.narrative:
To achieve its objectives HEARD targets; researchers, decision makers in key policy positions at national and regional level and community level advocates across the East and Southern African region. HEARD employs three key strategies to engage its target groups to generate evidence and disseminate evidence through; establishing research clusters, funding PhD studentships, curating technical workshops or technical knowledge consulting where requested, and hosting and moderating high level meetings in the region to advocate for evidence informed reforms. The short-term progress of HEARD’s programme strategy is in part benchmarked by Sida's Agreement with HEARD. In the agreement, the rate at which evidence is generated through research clusters that produce datasets, policy briefs, journal articles, and presentations is set at at least two research clusters per year. Capacity strengthening is bench marked by 15 PhD studentships and 4 workshops/events targeting research, policy, planning and health management technocrats each year. HEARD’s ability to influence key decision making spaces is also related to its ability to provide technical assistance to key mulitlaterals and regional institutions to influence strategic thinking such as the UN, AU, Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tubeculosis and Malaria (GFATM) and the SADC parliamentary forum. HEARD plays a key role in advocacy by chairing and hosting high level meeting events and targets at least one high level meeting a year. A summary of HEARD’s progress in 2019 against targets and past performance is summarised in the following sections.
Applied Research In 2019 HEARD continued to publish prolifically and expanded its research scope through two additional research clusters; the Men, Masculinities and HIV/SRH cluster as well as the universal health coverage (UHC) and SRHR cluster which aims to increase understanding of how SRHR can be effectively prioritized within UHC reforms. A few relevant examples of interesting research relevant to the SRHR strategy are articles that explore adolescent sexuality in boys [1] and whether GFATAM frameworks support countries in Africa to demonstrate ownership and transparency incountry coordinating mechanisms [2]. Other research examples in 2019 can be found at: https://www.heard.org.za/publications. Capacity Strengthening PhD Training The focus of research work is increasingly being attached to the work of the research clusters. One example would be PhD research that is part of a two-year project, funded by Campus France and the National Research Fund, South Africa, looking at violence against women migrants and refugees, analysing causes and effective policy responses. More broadly in 2019, five of HEARD’s PhD students joined established researchers and key stakeholders in the area of SRH to present and discuss their work at a special HEARD-hosted seminar on the SRH of young people in East and Southern Africa, looking at current issues and opportunities for collaborative research, policy and practice. By the end of 2019 it was expected that the HEARD PhD programme would have enrolled 30 PhD students. So far just over half the target have been enrolled (17), and two have since dropped out. Although hundreds of candidates apply to the programme annually, HEARD only awards scholarships to candidates meeting the necessary criteria to ensure they complete the programme in the stipulated amount of time. Workshops and Technical Assistance In 2019 HEARD built capacity in multilaterals, regional researchers and governments to improve the way they work to further SRHR in the region. HEARD uses its expertise, networks and depth of knowledge to push boundaries. As such, research on Lesbians Gays Bisexuals Transgender and Intersex communities became a key background document for the GFATM regional activities [3]. At the same time, HEARD convened a series of round-table discussions with representatives of key populations to explore achievements and on-going challenges to advance human rights and social justice in Africa. On abortion, HEARD claims to be advising the Ministries of Health in Malawi, Lesotho, Swaziland and Zimbabwe on on-going constitutional amendment to abortion laws. In Malawi, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Kenya and Namibia, HEARD claims that it advocates for a shift in the narrative and growing understanding and acceptance of a wider definition of SRHR and its fundamental role in UHC. One example of their success is GFATM's re-engagement of HEARD to provide technical support for the development of five national plans to address and remove the barriers for key populations to access essential health services and integrated SRH services. HEARD provided this support to Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda. Another example is how HEARD wrote a position paper on Africa’s progress towards UHC by focusing on the need to track essential services which was said to be later adopted by the World Bank and World Health Organization. To support regional researchers, HEARD researchers provided technical assistance to the African Population and Health Research Centre (APHRC) to undertake political economic analyses. APHRC is leading a multi-country collaborative study on the politics of social exclusion for key populations in countries in east and southern Africa. At a country level, HEARD also provided expert technical support for a comprehensive review of the South Sudan national HIV programme. The review was completed in March 2020. In South Africa, HEARD has supported the development and pilot of, and educator training in, a package of Scripted Lesson Plans for Grades 4-6, 7-9 and 10-12 to support educators in effective delivery of comprehensive sexuality education in the classroom. The plans are rights-based, scientifically accurate, age appropriate, contextual and relevant lesson plans which have already reached almost 300 000 learners. High Level Meetings and Advocacy There are three examples of how HEARD used its independent position to influence leaders and potential changes makers in 2019. Between March and July of 2019, HEARD convened six cabinet retreats (jointly with World Bank and Africa Development Bank) to discuss the fiscal implications for African countries looking to adopt UHC health benefits packages. Another example is how HEARD and the World Bank Global AIDS Program co-hosted the third meeting of the ESA Advisory Committee on Investment, Efficiency and Sustainability for the AIDS response. In another example, HEARD used its position to propose that the Africa Union and Africa Development Bank lead in the creation of an institutional mechanism with the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) to manage health service delivery basic packages of care and frameworks that do not exceed what is affordable for the majority on the continent. The outcome document was served at the ECA annual Ministerial Conference of Finance Ministers in November 2019. HEARD's reported progress is yet to be verified.
